newsitem.title: FINLAND: Helsinki at life-high but profit-takers dent Nokia.
newsitem.headline: Helsinki at life-high but profit-takers dent Nokia.

text.p: Shares managed a new life high in bumper volumes after a result-packed session led by Nokia on Thursday. But brokers were wary and, as profit-takers moved in late on the telecoms stock, saw room for a correction.

The HEX general index ended at the 2,855.97 point session low, up 0.73 percent, clearly below the 2,887.75 life-high set earlier but still its highest close ever. Volume was a massive 1.4 billion markka.

A 21 percent profit drop in 1996 plus a dividend hike from Nokia initially seemed to satisfy investors, and the stock held pre-result gains. But some profit-taking had been seen on the cards and by the close, Nokia was off four markka at 319.00.
"In money terms, the result was exactly what was expected, but it wasn't any more than that, so these expectations have already been priced in," one broker said.
Stockholm market sources also cited rumours Goldman Sachs had downgraded Nokia, which it denied. Analyst Richard Kramer said Goldman had Nokia as "outperform".

One broker said Nokia had presented a very encouraging picture in its conference call with analysts: "They had good things to say about all their lines of business. The outlook is really good," he said.
Another saw Nokia sticking around 300-330 markka near term.
Elsewhere, Rautaruukki saw plenty of action and picked up 2.30 markka or over five percent to 44.50 after sounding upbeat on prospects and with results in line with the market's view.

Kesko put on 1.80 markka to 72.50 markka after its report beat expectations and Raisio rose nearly four percent to 440.00 -- but in fairly thin volumes -- after its report came in at the high end of market forecasts.

Amer fell 2.00 markka to 102.00 after reporting a wider-than-expected loss for 1996: "The share could have fallen more than it did." said one broker. "Evidently some foreign investors still think Amer is a good investment."
After rallies in other forestry stocks, Metsa-Serla attracted unusually heavy interest, adding 2.10 markka to 40.50, but brokers could identify no special reason.
